blog.name: jackoshadows
blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.

tags: The Northern Lords on the show are useless whiny idiotic shitheads
When will we see the bad-ass lords from the books?
summary:
At the end of the day, when Jon goes back to the North, the
people who truly respect and love him will be on his side and...
body:
At the end of the day, when Jon goes back to the North, the people who truly respect and love him will be on his side and understand that he made the right decision. These people include:

Arya, who was ready to chop off some heads because the lords were insulting Jon and talking treason.

Bran, who truly understands the gravity of the threat and what’s needed to defeat the WW.

The Wildlings who have fought and died for Jon and are loyal to him.

Lyanna Mormont who gave her 62 men to fight in the BOTB because her father thought Jon was the best man to fight the WW

Anyone else? If the likes of Glover - treasonous weather vanes - want to kick Jon out because he bend the knee, they can come up with their own way to defeat the WW. Glover had no issues with the Boltons as wardens of the North answering to the Lannisters of KL. But suddenly, when Dany comes to save them, Northern independence would be more important than an apocalyptic threat?

If they start talking bs, Jon should let them make Sansa QITN, ask them to deal with the WW on their own and peace out with Dany, Arya, Bran and Ghost. But he’s too good for that. So we will have to once again sit through Jon tiredly dealing with a bunch of naysayers shitting all over his plans.

It’s also hilarious how rabid Stark/Sansa fans go on and on about Northern independence and Dany not respecting their rights. They should ask Theon Greyjoy about how he felt being a child hostage in Winterfell because his father wanted independence for the Iron Islands. So it’s all okay for Ned Stark to attack the Iron Islands because they dared to fight for independence, but everyone should respect the North’s right to independence? This hypocrisy and double standards are what is typical of the Stark fandom. It’s one rule for the Starks and another for everyone else.

Hopefully Northern shitheads like Glover have enough brain cells to realize that they need Dany’s help and band together to defeat the common threat rather than bitch and whine about Jon doing the needful.

blog.name: queenofpanache
blog.title: ICE QUEEN
blog.description: Everything before the word 'but' is horse shit. - Jon Snow

summary: Just a question I have. Why can't a three-eyed raven become a lord?

blog.name: tatticstudio55
blog.title: pro jonerys who likes healthy debates

summary: Do dragons and direwolves fare well together?
title: Do dragons and direwolves fare well together?
body:
@geekyfeminist-love @northernlights37 @glitta @oadara

I went through Bran’s POV chapters in ACOK, gathering every possible reference to direwolves and dragons, because, well, we were told that “there are far too many passages in ASOIAF that hint at animosity between direwolves and dragons.” Hum.

1)      Summer and Shaggydog howling at the red comet.

Summer’s howls were long and sad, full of grief and longing. Shaggydog’s were more savage.

[…]

“It’s freedom they’re calling for,” declared Farlen, who was kennelmaster and had no more love for the direwolves than his hounds did. “They don’t like being walled up, and who’s to blame them? Wild things belong in the wild, not in a castle.”

“They want to hunt,” agreed Gage the cook as he tossed cubes of suet in a great kettle of stew. “A wolf smells better'n any man. Like as not, they’ve caught the scent o’ prey.”

Maester Luwin did not think so. “Wolves often howl at the moon. These are howling at the comet. See how bright it is, Bran? Perchance they think it is the moon.”

When Bran repeated that to Osha, she laughed aloud. “Your wolves have more wit than your maester,” the wildling woman said. “They know truths the grey man has forgotten.” The way she said it made him shiver, and when he asked what the comet meant, she answered, “Blood and fire, boy, and nothing sweet.”

Bran asked Septon Chayle about the comet while they were sorting through some scrolls snatched from the library fire. “It is the sword that slays the season,” he replied, and soon after the white raven came from Oldtown bringing word of autumn, so doubtless he was right.

Though Old Nan did not think so, and she’d lived longer than any of them. “Dragons,” she said, lifting her head and sniffing. She was near blind and could not see the comet, yet she claimed she could smell it. “It be dragons, boy,” she insisted. Bran got no princes from Nan, no more than he ever had.

[…]

And still the direwolves howled. The guards on the walls muttered curses, hounds in the kennels barked furiously, horses kicked at their stalls, the Walders shivered by their fire, and even Maester Luwin complained of sleepless nights. Only Bran did not mind.

[…]

It was dark amongst the trees, but the comet lit his way, and his feet were sure. He was moving on four good legs, strong and swift, and he could feel the ground underfoot, the soft crackling of fallen leaves, thick roots and hard stones, the deep layers of humus. It was a good feeling.

Summer’s howls are described as long and sad, full of grief and longing. We see different animals (and humans) react differently to the comet: the hounds with fury, the horses with agitation, the Walders with fear. But the direwolves? With sadness, grief and longing – it doesn’t exactly point to a visceral animosity towards dragons. We’re told that they’re restless, that they want to leave the castle, and Bran’s wolf dream inside Summer gives us even more perspective, since it looks like Summer’s following the comet, all the while being simply content at doing so. Surely, he knows what he’s following. If Old Nan can “sniff” dragons, direwolves can too.

2)      But what about that time when Summer growled at the winged serpent atop Winterfell?

Men, many men, many horses, and fire, fire, fire. No smell was more dangerous, not even the hard cold smell of iron, the stuff of man-claws and hardskin. The smoke and ash clouded his eyes, and in the sky he saw a great winged snake whose roar was a river of flame. He bared his teeth, but then the snake was gone. Behind the cliffs tall fires were eating up the stars.

First, we should be reminded that Summer and Shaggydog bare their teeth a lot: toward each other when they fight for food, toward Jojen Reed for questioning Bran too insistently, toward little Walders for pushing Rickon in the water (even though they were just playing), etc. In ACOK, we mostly see them being aggressive when Bran and Rickon are either 1) angered, or 2) in perceived danger/threatened by something/someone, so Summer’s reaction at witnessing a “beast” burning down Bran’s home isn’t surprising. Of course, one could wonder why the winged snake had to be put there in the first place if it meant nothing. To which I’d argue that it does indeed mean something… else. So, we know that Bran&Co were hiding in the crypts the night Winterfell burned. Then, the following morning:

“Hodor hodor hodor hodor hodor HODOR!” From above came a dull rumble. Then suddenly the door jerked upward and a shaft of daylight fell across Bran’s face, blinding him for a moment. Another shove brought the sound of shifting stone, and then the way was open. Osha poked her spear through and slid out after it, and Rickon squirmed through Meera’s legs to follow. Hodor shoved the door open all the way and stepped to the surface. The Reeds had to carry Bran up the last few steps.

The sky was a pale grey, and smoke eddied all around them. They stood in the shadow of the First Keep, or what remained of it. One whole side of the building had torn loose and fallen away. Stone and shattered gargoyles lay strewn across the yard. They fell just where I did, Bran thought when he saw them. Some of the gargoyles had broken into so many pieces it made him wonder how he was alive at all. Nearby some crows were pecking at a body crushed beneath the tumbled stone, but he lay facedown and Bran could not say who he was.

The First Keep had not been used for many hundreds of years, but now it was more of a shell than ever. The floors had burned inside it, and all the beams. Where the wall had fallen away, they could see right into the rooms, even into the privy. Yet behind, the broken tower still stood, no more burned than before. Jojen Reed was coughing from the smoke. “Take me home!” Rickon demanded. “I want to be home!” Hodor stomped in a circle. “Hodor,” he whimpered in a small voice. They stood huddled together with ruin and death all around them.

“We made noise enough to wake a dragon,” Osha said, “but there’s no one come. The castle’s dead and burned, just as Bran dreamed, but we had best - ” She broke off suddenly at a noise behind them, and whirled with her spear at the ready.

It’s interesting that Osha joke about “making enough noise to wake a dragon” when they’re surrounded by dead (who couldn’t be woken up no matter what), tumbled stones and broken gargoyles (is this a hint to the prophetic awakening of dragons from stones?) It’s even more interesting that the party just emerged from the Winterfell’s crypts, and clearly not from a regular exit either (Hodor’s efforts at pushing open the door have some Lazarus undertones), so if we take the scene as a metaphor, Osha, Bran, Rickon, Hodor, Meera and Jojen are the ones being awoken from the dead – even carrying the dead’s weapons:

Osha carried her long oaken spear in one hand and the torch in the other. A naked sword hung down her back, one of the last to bear Mikken’s mark. He had forged it for Lord Eddard’s tomb, to keep his ghost at rest. But with Mikken slain and the ironmen guarding the armory, good steel had been hard to resist, even if it meant grave-robbing. Meera had claimed Lord Rickard’s blade, though she complained that it was too heavy. Brandon took his namesake’s, the sword made for the uncle he had never known. He knew he would not be much use in a fight, but even so the blade felt good in his hand.

To get back to the “winged snake”, I think it was put there to draw a parallel between the dragons woken from stones and Bran&Co themselves being “woken” from stones (remember the tumbling of stones when Hodor finally managed to open that door). Both events were linked with the return of magic: Dany birthing dragons and Bran learning to “see” with his third eye in the crypt:

Here in the chill damp darkness of the tomb his third eye had finally opened.

I’ll finish with another passage between Jon, Daenerys and Ghost Bran, Meera and Summer:

Laughing, the Reed girl threw her arms around the tangled wolf and rolled them both. Summer gave a piteous whine, his legs kicking against the cords that bound them. Meera knelt, undid a twist, pulled at a corner, tugged deftly here and there, and suddenly the direwolf was bounding free.

[…]

Meera shook her head. “Does he never grow angry?”

“Not with me.” Bran grabbed the wolf by his ears and Summer snapped at him fiercely, but it was all in play. “Sometimes he tears my garb but he’s never drawn blood.”

“Your blood, you mean. If he’d gotten past my net … ”

“He wouldn’t hurt you. He knows I like you.”

Hodor shoved the door open all the way and stepped to the surface. The Reeds had to carry Bran up the last few steps.

The sky was a pale grey, and smoke eddied all around them. They stood in the shadow of the First Keep, or what remained of it. One whole side of the building had torn loose and fallen away. Stone and shattered gargoyles lay strewn across the yard. They fell just where I did, Bran thought when he saw them. Some of the gargoyles had broken into so many pieces it made him wonder how he was alive at all. Nearby some crows were pecking at a body crushed beneath the tumbled stone, but he lay facedown and Bran could not say who he was.

The First Keep had not been used for many hundreds of years, but now it was more of a shell than ever. The floors had burned inside it, and all the beams. Where the wall had fallen away, they could see right into the rooms, even into the privy. Yet behind, the broken tower still stood, no more burned than before. Jojen Reed was coughing from the smoke. “Take me home!” Rickon demanded. “I want to be home!” Hodor stomped in a circle. “Hodor,” he whimpered in a small voice. They stood huddled together with ruin and death all around them.

“We made noise enough to wake a dragon,” Osha said, “but there’s no one come. The castle’s dead and burned, just as Bran dreamed, but we had best - ” She broke off suddenly at a noise behind them, and whirled with her spear at the ready.

It’s interesting that Osha joke about “making enough noise to wake a dragon” when they’re surrounded by dead (who couldn’t be woken up no matter what), tumbled stones and broken gargoyles (is this a hint to the prophetic awakening of dragons from stones?) It’s even more interesting that the party just emerged from the Winterfell’s crypts, and clearly not from a regular exit either (Hodor’s efforts at pushing open the door have some Lazarus undertones), so if we take the scene as a metaphor, Osha, Bran, Rickon, Hodor, Meera and Jojen are the ones being awoken from the dead – even carrying the dead’s weapons:

Osha carried her long oaken spear in one hand and the torch in the other. A naked sword hung down her back, one of the last to bear Mikken’s mark. He had forged it for Lord Eddard’s tomb, to keep his ghost at rest. But with Mikken slain and the ironmen guarding the armory, good steel had been hard to resist, even if it meant grave-robbing. Meera had claimed Lord Rickard’s blade, though she complained that it was too heavy. Brandon took his namesake’s, the sword made for the uncle he had never known. He knew he would not be much use in a fight, but even so the blade felt good in his hand.

To get back to the “winged snake”, I think it was put there to draw a parallel between the dragons woken from stones and Bran&Co themselves being “woken” from stones (remember the tumbling of stones when Hodor finally managed to open that door). Both events were linked with the return of magic: Dany birthing dragons and Bran learning to “see” with his third eye in the crypt:

Here in the chill damp darkness of the tomb his third eye had finally opened.

I’ll finish with another passage between Jon, Daenerys and Ghost Bran, Meera and Summer:

Laughing, the Reed girl threw her arms around the tangled wolf and rolled them both. Summer gave a piteous whine, his legs kicking against the cords that bound them. Meera knelt, undid a twist, pulled at a corner, tugged deftly here and there, and suddenly the direwolf was bounding free.

[…]

Meera shook her head. “Does he never grow angry?”

“Not with me.” Bran grabbed the wolf by his ears and Summer snapped at him fiercely, but it was all in play. “Sometimes he tears my garb but he’s never drawn blood.”

“Your blood, you mean. If he’d gotten past my net … ”

“He wouldn’t hurt you. He knows I like you.”
trail.content:
@geekyfeminist-love @northernlights37 @glitta @oadara

I went through Bran’s POV chapters in ACOK, gathering every possible reference to direwolves and dragons, because, well, we were told that “there are far too many passages in ASOIAF that hint at animosity between direwolves and dragons.” Hum.

1)      Summer and Shaggydog howling at the red comet.

Summer’s howls were long and sad, full of grief and longing. Shaggydog’s were more savage.

[…]

“It’s freedom they’re calling for,” declared Farlen, who was kennelmaster and had no more love for the direwolves than his hounds did. “They don’t like being walled up, and who’s to blame them? Wild things belong in the wild, not in a castle.”

“They want to hunt,” agreed Gage the cook as he tossed cubes of suet in a great kettle of stew. “A wolf smells better'n any man. Like as not, they’ve caught the scent o’ prey.”

Maester Luwin did not think so. “Wolves often howl at the moon. These are howling at the comet. See how bright it is, Bran? Perchance they think it is the moon.”

When Bran repeated that to Osha, she laughed aloud. “Your wolves have more wit than your maester,” the wildling woman said. “They know truths the grey man has forgotten.” The way she said it made him shiver, and when he asked what the comet meant, she answered, “Blood and fire, boy, and nothing sweet.”

Bran asked Septon Chayle about the comet while they were sorting through some scrolls snatched from the library fire. “It is the sword that slays the season,” he replied, and soon after the white raven came from Oldtown bringing word of autumn, so doubtless he was right.

Though Old Nan did not think so, and she’d lived longer than any of them. “Dragons,” she said, lifting her head and sniffing. She was near blind and could not see the comet, yet she claimed she could smell it. “It be dragons, boy,” she insisted. Bran got no princes from Nan, no more than he ever had.

[…]

And still the direwolves howled. The guards on the walls muttered curses, hounds in the kennels barked furiously, horses kicked at their stalls, the Walders shivered by their fire, and even Maester Luwin complained of sleepless nights. Only Bran did not mind.

[…]

It was dark amongst the trees, but the comet lit his way, and his feet were sure. He was moving on four good legs, strong and swift, and he could feel the ground underfoot, the soft crackling of fallen leaves, thick roots and hard stones, the deep layers of humus. It was a good feeling.

Summer’s howls are described as long and sad, full of grief and longing. We see different animals (and humans) react differently to the comet: the hounds with fury, the horses with agitation, the Walders with fear. But the direwolves? With sadness, grief and longing – it doesn’t exactly point to a visceral animosity towards dragons. We’re told that they’re restless, that they want to leave the castle, and Bran’s wolf dream inside Summer gives us even more perspective, since it looks like Summer’s following the comet, all the while being simply content at doing so. Surely, he knows what he’s following. If Old Nan can “sniff” dragons, direwolves can too.

2)      But what about that time when Summer growled at the winged serpent atop Winterfell?

Men, many men, many horses, and fire, fire, fire. No smell was more dangerous, not even the hard cold smell of iron, the stuff of man-claws and hardskin. The smoke and ash clouded his eyes, and in the sky he saw a great winged snake whose roar was a river of flame. He bared his teeth, but then the snake was gone. Behind the cliffs tall fires were eating up the stars.

First, we should be reminded that Summer and Shaggydog bare their teeth a lot: toward each other when they fight for food, toward Jojen Reed for questioning Bran too insistently, toward little Walders for pushing Rickon in the water (even though they were just playing), etc. In ACOK, we mostly see them being aggressive when Bran and Rickon are either 1) angered, or 2) in perceived danger/threatened by something/someone, so Summer’s reaction at witnessing a “beast” burning down Bran’s home isn’t surprising. Of course, one could wonder why the winged snake had to be put there in the first place if it meant nothing. To which I’d argue that it does indeed mean something… else. So, we know that Bran&Co were hiding in the crypts the night Winterfell burned. Then, the following morning:

“Hodor hodor hodor hodor hodor HODOR!” From above came a dull rumble. Then suddenly the door jerked upward and a shaft of daylight fell across Bran’s face, blinding him for a moment. Another shove brought the sound of shifting stone, and then the way was open. Osha poked her spear through and slid out after it, and Rickon squirmed through Meera’s legs to follow. Hodor shoved the door open all the way and stepped to the surface. The Reeds had to carry Bran up the last few steps.

The sky was a pale grey, and smoke eddied all around them. They stood in the shadow of the First Keep, or what remained of it. One whole side of the building had torn loose and fallen away. Stone and shattered gargoyles lay strewn across the yard. They fell just where I did, Bran thought when he saw them. Some of the gargoyles had broken into so many pieces it made him wonder how he was alive at all. Nearby some crows were pecking at a body crushed beneath the tumbled stone, but he lay facedown and Bran could not say who he was.

The First Keep had not been used for many hundreds of years, but now it was more of a shell than ever. The floors had burned inside it, and all the beams. Where the wall had fallen away, they could see right into the rooms, even into the privy. Yet behind, the broken tower still stood, no more burned than before. Jojen Reed was coughing from the smoke. “Take me home!” Rickon demanded. “I want to be home!” Hodor stomped in a circle. “Hodor,” he whimpered in a small voice. They stood huddled together with ruin and death all around them.

“We made noise enough to wake a dragon,” Osha said, “but there’s no one come. The castle’s dead and burned, just as Bran dreamed, but we had best - ” She broke off suddenly at a noise behind them, and whirled with her spear at the ready.

It’s interesting that Osha joke about “making enough noise to wake a dragon” when they’re surrounded by dead (who couldn’t be woken up no matter what), tumbled stones and broken gargoyles (is this a hint to the prophetic awakening of dragons from stones?) It’s even more interesting that the party just emerged from the Winterfell’s crypts, and clearly not from a regular exit either (Hodor’s efforts at pushing open the door have some Lazarus undertones), so if we take the scene as a metaphor, Osha, Bran, Rickon, Hodor, Meera and Jojen are the ones being awoken from the dead – even carrying the dead’s weapons:

Osha carried her long oaken spear in one hand and the torch in the other. A naked sword hung down her back, one of the last to bear Mikken’s mark. He had forged it for Lord Eddard’s tomb, to keep his ghost at rest. But with Mikken slain and the ironmen guarding the armory, good steel had been hard to resist, even if it meant grave-robbing. Meera had claimed Lord Rickard’s blade, though she complained that it was too heavy. Brandon took his namesake’s, the sword made for the uncle he had never known. He knew he would not be much use in a fight, but even so the blade felt good in his hand.

To get back to the “winged snake”, I think it was put there to draw a parallel between the dragons woken from stones and Bran&Co themselves being “woken” from stones (remember the tumbling of stones when Hodor finally managed to open that door). Both events were linked with the return of magic: Dany birthing dragons and Bran learning to “see” with his third eye in the crypt:

Here in the chill damp darkness of the tomb his third eye had finally opened.

I’ll finish with another passage between Jon, Daenerys and Ghost Bran, Meera and Summer:

Laughing, the Reed girl threw her arms around the tangled wolf and rolled them both. Summer gave a piteous whine, his legs kicking against the cords that bound them. Meera knelt, undid a twist, pulled at a corner, tugged deftly here and there, and suddenly the direwolf was bounding free.

[…]

Meera shook her head. “Does he never grow angry?”

“Not with me.” Bran grabbed the wolf by his ears and Summer snapped at him fiercely, but it was all in play. “Sometimes he tears my garb but he’s never drawn blood.”

“Your blood, you mean. If he’d gotten past my net … ”

“He wouldn’t hurt you. He knows I like you.”

summary: What if jon snow does not come back from death? Do you think it's possible?
question: What if jon snow does not come back from death? Do you think it's possible?
answer:
if he dies, the story continues without him. the other starks are still alive and so is daenerys. in my personal opinion, i don’t see what is so essential about him that he needs to be there in the great war. daenerys has the dragons and bran is the three eyed raven, what does jon have besides a valyrian sword? personally it would strengthen the story if he did stay dead. after all like ned people would think he was the hero of the story, he has to come back from the dead but when he doesn’t it would really pull the rug from under everyone’s feet and force them to accept that the saviours are a disabled boy, two young girls and a dragon queen.

unfortunately, he’s going to come back to life in the books, become a candidate for king in the north, meet daenerys, have a blah romance with her and then fight the others. unbelievably dull.

unfortunately, he’s going to come back to life in the books, become a candidate for king in the north, meet daenerys, have a blah romance with her and then fight the others. unbelievably dull.

unfortunately, he’s going to come back to life in the books, become a candidate for king in the north, meet daenerys, have a blah romance with her and then fight the others. unbelievably dull.

I appear to have tumbled back down into Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire Fandom again (Jaime/Brienne, Dany/Jorah, Jon/Sansa, amongst other pairings). I'm still living that Star Trek Fan Life (mostly Voyager [Janeway/Chakotay OTP) and Discovery (Admiral Katrina Cornwell and Captain Philippa Georgiou focus). I cannot possibly list everything I might reblog, but forever carrying a torch for Veronica Mars (I live a Weevil appreciation life), Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries, Doctor Who (Nine, Martha Jones), Roslin/Adama, Buffy/Faith, Aral/Cordelia, amongst others.


Testimonial by wakeupgreat:

"lodessa is an amazing human! she can be recognized in the wild by her inara icon and is known across the land for star trek rpf and for being into a song of ice and fire long before it was a tv show. she is a fellow fandom oldie and we relate on many levels. also once she wrote me cersei/brienne so basically she is the BEST."

summary:
“Iron Maiden”
My armor isn’t armor
But more of an Iron Maiden.
On the surface is a frozen smile
It is cold, unscathed, strong...
body:
“Iron Maiden”

My armor isn’t armor

But more of an Iron Maiden.

On the surface is a frozen smile

It is cold, unscathed, strong plating.

Inside however is a bleeding, mangled soul

Who cries for help, but fears she is forsakened

Though she calls out anyway, when you hear it,

The Maiden lies, “You must be mistaken”.

“I’m okay”

“I’m fine”

“Don’t worry about me”

“I’m used to it”

C’est le Vie

Though she calls out anyway, when you hear it,

“I’m used to it”

C’est le Vie

“Iron Maiden”

My armor isn’t armor

But more of an Iron Maiden.

On the surface is a frozen smile

It is cold, unscathed, strong plating.

Inside however is a bleeding, mangled soul

Who cries for help, but fears she is forsakened

Though she calls out anyway, when you hear it,

The Maiden lies, “You must be mistaken”.

“I’m okay”

“I’m fine”

“Don’t worry about me”

“I’m used to it”

C’est le Vie
trail.content:
“Iron Maiden”

My armor isn’t armor

But more of an Iron Maiden.

On the surface is a frozen smile

It is cold, unscathed, strong plating.

Inside however is a bleeding, mangled soul

Who cries for help, but fears she is forsakened

Though she calls out anyway, when you hear it,

The Maiden lies, “You must be mistaken”.

“I’m okay”

“I’m fine”

“Don’t worry about me”

“I’m used to it”

C’est le Vie

summary: What are your thoughts on a world where Arya is Wardeness of the North and Sansa is Lady of Winterfell? I saw someone on reddit...
question: What are your thoughts on a world where Arya is Wardeness of the North and Sansa is Lady of Winterfell? I saw someone on reddit speculate about it since Sansa is currently v much higher than her sister in role and title, and that would even the playing field. It could even work in book canon, with them playing the roles for either a young Rickon or Bran (although if it was  Bran, Sansa's role would obviously be more Lady Stark than Lord Stark -esque).
answer: I don’t see either of them taking authority positions over their brothers at the moment. First of all, they’re all super close in age; there’s no need for them to assume power when Bran is nearly as old, and has actual experienced people around him to help. Second, neither girl has the experience that Bran has to be able to take on those roles over him. Bran has actually dealt with the politics of Winterfell firsthand as acting lord. Nothing Sansa or Arya can do will trump that experience or knowledge. Third of all, Jon is (or will be, if we’re talking the books) alive, and he has extensive experience in leadership and northern-based politics. Sticking Arya and Sansa in these roles (at least right now) makes zero sense when their remaining brothers have a combined political career that has dealt with battle, food rations, delegation, execution, sacrifice, negotiations, etc.
